factoid: The two Pávlograd squadrons crossed the bridge.
The two Pávlograd squadrons retired up the hill one after the other.
Karl Bogdánich Schubert is the colonel of the Pávlograd squadrons.
Karl Bogdánich Schubert approached Denísov’s squadron.
Karl Bogdánich Schubert rode at a footpace not far from Rostóv.
Karl Bogdánich Schubert did not notice Rostóv.
Karl Bogdánich Schubert and Rostóv were meeting for the first time since their encounter concerning Telyánin.
Rostóv felt that Rostóv was at the front.
Rostóv felt that Rostóv was in the power of Karl Bogdánich Schubert.
Rostóv admitted that Rostóv had been to blame toward Karl Bogdánich Schubert.
Rostóv did not lift his eyes from Karl Bogdánich Schubert’s back.
Karl Bogdánich Schubert’s nape was covered with light hair.
Karl Bogdánich Schubert had a red neck.
Rostóv thought that Karl Bogdánich Schubert was pretending not to notice him.
Rostóv thought that Karl Bogdánich Schubert’s aim was to test the cadet’s courage.
Rostóv drew himself up and looked around merrily.
Rostóv thought that Karl Bogdánich Schubert rode near to show him his courage.
Rostóv thought that his enemy would send the squadron on a desperate attack to punish him.
Rostóv imagined that after the attack Karl Bogdánich Schubert would come up to him while he lay wounded.
Rostóv imagined that Karl Bogdánich Schubert would extend the hand of reconciliation.
Zherkóv had a high-shouldered figure.
Zherkóv was familiar to the Pávlograds.
Zherkóv had recently left the Pávlograds’ regiment.
Zherkóv rode up to Karl Bogdánich Schubert.
After his dismissal from headquarters, Zherkóv did not remain in the regiment.
Zherkóv said he was not a fool to serve at the front when he could earn more rewards by doing nothing on the staff.
Zherkóv became an orderly officer to Prince Bagratión.
Zherkóv brought an order from the commander of the rear guard to Karl Bogdánich Schubert.
Zherkóv told Karl Bogdánich Schubert that there was an order to stop and fire the bridge.
Karl Bogdánich Schubert asked who the order was for.
Zherkóv said he did not know to whom the order was addressed.
Zherkóv said the prince told him to go and tell Karl Bogdánich Schubert that the hussars must return quickly and fire the bridge.
An officer of the suite followed Zherkóv.
The officer of the suite rode up to Karl Bogdánich Schubert with the same order.
Nesvítski galloped up on a Cossack horse.
Nesvítski was stout.
The Cossack horse could scarcely carry Nesvítski’s weight.
Nesvítski shouted at Karl Bogdánich Schubert.
Nesvítski told Karl Bogdánich Schubert that he had told him to fire the bridge.
Nesvítski said that someone had gone and blundered.
Nesvítski said that the people were beside themselves over there.
Nesvítski said that one could not make anything out.
Karl Bogdánich Schubert deliberately stopped the regiment.
Karl Bogdánich Schubert turned to Nesvítski.
Karl Bogdánich Schubert said that Nesvítski had spoken about inflammable material.
Karl Bogdánich Schubert said that Nesvítski had said nothing about firing it.
Nesvítski said that he had been telling Karl Bogdánich Schubert to fire the bridge.
Nesvítski said that inflammable material had been put in position.
Nesvítski said that Karl Bogdánich Schubert was not his dear sir.
Nesvítski said that Karl Bogdánich Schubert had not told him to burn the bridge.
Nesvítski said that he knows the service.
Nesvítski said that he habitually obeys orders strictly.
Nesvítski said that Karl Bogdánich Schubert said the bridge would be burned.
Nesvítski said that he could not know who would burn the bridge by the holy spirit.
Nesvítski said that is always the way.
Nesvítski asked Zherkóv how he got there.
Nesvítski said that he was on the same business.
Nesvítski said that Zherkóv was damp.
Nesvítski offered to wring Zherkóv out.
The officer of the suite interrupted Karl Bogdánich Schubert.
The officer of the suite told Karl Bogdánich Schubert that the enemy would bring up guns to use grapeshot.
The officer of the suite said that Karl Bogdánich Schubert must be quick.
Karl Bogdánich Schubert looked at the officer of the suite.
Karl Bogdánich Schubert looked at the stout staff officer.
Karl Bogdánich Schubert looked at Zherkóv.
Karl Bogdánich Schubert frowned.
Karl Bogdánich Schubert said that he would fire the bridge.
Karl Bogdánich Schubert announced that he would still do the right thing.
Karl Bogdánich Schubert struck his horse with his long muscular legs.
Karl Bogdánich Schubert moved forward.
Karl Bogdánich Schubert ordered the second squadron to return to the bridge.
The second squadron served under Denísov.
Rostóv served in the second squadron.
Rostóv thought that Karl Bogdánich Schubert wished to test him.
Rostóv felt his heart contracted.
Rostóv felt blood rushed to his face.
Rostóv thought that he would let Karl Bogdánich Schubert see whether he is a coward.
